passages.text: Foreign Exchange - Asia ex-Japan/Euro Area/Europe
What is the MAXIMUM gain in August NFP that will lead to an immediate weakening of the USD (consensus \(\sim 78K\) )?

- US August NFP are key, but watch developments on Fed independence, Japan's political situation (2 September), and the US on Russia-Ukraine. Our bias is still broadly in the short USD camp, and we see some strong performance in long EUR/INR.
- Asia FX: We maintain high conviction levels (4/5) on our long EUR/INR, and lower the conviction levels on our short USD/IDR and short CNH versus basket to 3/5 (from 4).

- G10 FX: Into the US jobs report next week, we retain our short USD/JPY (4/5), and raise the conviction for our short USD/SEK (to 4/5 was 3/5). The French political situation is unlikely to go strongly against our long EUR/CHF (3/5), while stronger Q2 AU GDP should support our long AUD/CAD (3/5).
- Asia rates: We maintain a high conviction level of 4/5 on our receive Mar-26 1y Korea NDIRS (vs. US) and Dec-IMM 3s10s HK steepener (vs. US).
Fig. 1: Top five top-conviction strategy trades in order (scale 1-5)
Australia/New Zealand Rates Strategy
Note: Conviction scale: 1 - Watch; 2 - Watch Closely; 3 - Positioned @ 1/3 desired; 4 - Positioned @ 2/3 desired; 5 - Positioned @ 100% desired. Source: Nomura.

The USD has softened over the past week by \(\sim 70bp\) from before Powell's Jackson Hole speech, but the move has been relatively volatile and limited, despite Powell's modestly dovish stance, and President Trump's move to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook. There have been some positive developments for USD including uncertainty over French PM Bayrou (with a no- confidence vote on 8 September), the rise in long- end global yields
(JPY seeing some weakening pressures), and no shock to US equities from Nvidia's Q2 earnings. Inflows into US portfolio assets have also been stable since the Jackson Hole event.

Overall, despite some of these headwinds, we are still in the soft USD camp and will monitor a few key developments in the near- term. These include the US August NFP (5 September release; consensus last \(+78K; + 73K\) previous), where we believe a "slightly weaker" release (around \(+40K\) would lead the market to price in a full 25bp cut for September and 62.5bp in cuts by end- 2025 (i.e., 1.5 cuts for last two meetings). A "slightly weaker" release could also see some downside risk in US equities and accentuate recent inflows into EM equities, and we expect broad USD underperformance to emerge.

However, if NFP is notably weak at close to zero or below, there is a risk that the market will shift to front- loaded cuts from the Fed with the USD likely to see significant near- term weakness. We also see some risks that a weak NFP could lead to US equity weakness, but this is less of a clear positive for EM FX - especially if any near- term US equity correction is relatively sharp which could be favorable for our short USD against JPY position.

By contrast, if NFP is stronger than expected (such as around \(+150K+\) ), the risk is that the September FOMC meeting might be a close call (50- 50 likelihood of a cut), leading the USD initially or marginally higher with the next key determinant for the September FOMC being August core CPI data (11 September, consensus \(0.3\%\) m- o- m).

Payrolls aside, Fed independence concerns remain. NEC Chair Stephen Miran is due to be confirmed by the Senate in the week ahead to replace Kugler on the Fed board, which would mean Trump has selected three out of seven Fed Governors. Trump is likely to continue his push to remove Fed Board member Lisa Cook, even if she wins an injunction (in the near- term) against Trump's call to remove her. Trump having a majority of the Fed Board supporters will be important for the end- February 2026 selection of the regional Fed Presidents - giving Trump significant influence on Fed policy in 2026 ( \(\sim 70\) bp of cuts priced in the seven meetings from March to December 2026). The market is yet to react to the risk of full Fed control, as there are still uncertainties over the removal of Lisa Cook (Cook's removal would likely give Trump the support of four out of seven Fed Governors). Some market participants, whom we have discussed Fed risks with, believe Trump would likely retract his push on the Fed to ease aggressively if the move higher in longer- tenor US rates leads to a sharp sell- off in US equities. While possible, we would likely need to see a sharp sell- off in equities first for Trump to step back.

Other global events to watch/risks to the USD include: 1) if Japan's LDP Secretary General Moriyama resigns after the release of the Upper House election review (due on 2 September), as this could also lead to PM Ishiba stepping down as PM. This could raise some political instability concerns in Japan and lead to some near- term JPY weakness; 2) watch Russia- Ukraine developments, with limited signs of a meeting between the Russia and Ukraine leadership. With Russia's Putin, India's Modi, and China's Xi meeting at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization Summit (31 August to 1 September), this could further frustrate Trump in his Russia- Ukraine peace drive - raising the risk of Trump moving to more direct and indirect measures against Russia in the near- term. We continue to see India as the main loser if Trump's actions in relation to Russia- Ukraine are stepped up.

Strategy: to Asia FX, our key conviction trade is long EUR/INR (4/5 level). USD/INR has brokethrough the key 88- figure resistance level, with foreign portfolio flows remaining negative (especially equities). We continue to believe relative INR underperformance will continue and see some risks to the topside in USD/INR, as market participants suggest risk to corporate sector FX hedges (previous buying topside with EKOs around 89 and 90+ figures). Elsewhere in Asia, we lower the conviction levels on our short USD/IDR and short CNH basket to 3/5 (from 4) with Indonesia protests/riots being monitored, and some risk of positive RMB actions/China market actions into the 3 September China Victory Day Parade. We also hold onto our short USD vs. KRW and TWD recommendations (3/5), with TWD supported by our softer USD view, but also the significant underperformance since July, and stability in the tech sector after NVIDIA Q2 earnings (watch potential impact of August NFP on US equities).

In G10 FX, our top convictions (4/5) are in short USD/JPY and short USD/SEK. Asymmetry around the US data and USD will support these trades, but local focus points will remain on politics for JPY. For SEK, strengthening growth and inflation to come in

higher than the Riksbank's forecast (watch August CPI release on 4 Sep) could reduce rate cut expectations (23 September meeting). We also hold long AUD/CAD (3/5) with more positive macro support for Australia (Nomura economics forecasts Q2 GDP to rise \(0.6\%\) q- o- q; consensus \(0.5\%\) ; 3 September release).

In Asia rates, our top convictions are receive Mar- 26 1y NDIS vs. US and 3s10s HKD steepener vs. US (both 4/5). There is likely to be limited scope for Hong Kong front- end rates to bounce higher given the recent rise, while long- end K- US spreads are still low and might rise on better Hong Kong macro prospects. Korea continues to see limited rate cut pricing compared with that of the US, which this coming week's Korea inflation/trade data (if weaker) may see the market expect a lower terminal rate.

In India, we maintain a high conviction level on our long EUR/INR position at 4/5, targeting \(105.6\) ( \(\sim 10\%\) gains) by end- October (was end- September). Today, onshore spot USD/INR decisively broke above the market's perceived key level of 88.0 and above the historical high of 87.96 reached on 10 February 2025. We continue to see a solid rationale for this position to outperform: 1) USD/INR's break above historical highs suggested that the RBI does not have a line in the sand on defending INR, though the RBI will likely continue to smooth the move higher in spot. Indeed, we previously noted that the market may be overestimating just how much and how long the RBI will protect INR, given US- led policy shocks; 2) the EU's secondary sanctions aimed at imports of Russian oil is a new near- term risk for India. The EU's foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, said secondary sanctions aimed at Russia's energy sector would be most effective in curbing Moscow's ability to wage war against Ukraine (Bloomberg, 29 August). Bloomberg also reported (28 August) that the EU sanction package should be ready in a matter of weeks, and this could present an additional headwind for INR; 3) additional action from the Trump administration targeting India's imports of Russian oil also cannot be ruled out, especially as the Russia- Ukraine peace process appears to be stalling. Notably, Russia has continued with drone and missile strikes on Kyiv, in defiance of Trump's calls to cease fighting (Bloomberg, 28 August); 4) positioning risk from the corporate sectors' USD/INR topside FX hedges, if above 89- levels are breached. Our discussions with market participants suggest some risks to corporate sector FX hedges, where there has been buying of topside in USD/INR, with EKOs around 89 and \(90+\) figures. However, this may only lead to an incremental pick- up in USD demand if these FX hedges are knocked out, unlike the structured product- led selloff in INR in 2013; 5) August MTD (1- 26 August), India has seen foreign outflows of USD2.6bn from Indian equities, with a preliminary number for 28 August showing another USD440mn of outflows. We continue to see portfolio outflow pressures as tariff- related uncertainty remains. In addition to this, developments on PM Modi's visit to China (31 August - 1 September) for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization summit, where he is meeting Xi and Putin remains a key focus ahead.

In China, we lower (today) the conviction level on our short CNH against an equally weighted basket (EUR, AUD, KRW) to 3/5 (from 4), targeting \(4.0\%\) gains by end- October (was end- September). A few recent developments suggest the pace of CNH underperformance against its trading partners' currencies may slow in the near- term: a) the daily USD/CNY fixing has drifted lower at a faster pace over the past week, although the PBoC has started to show some unease about the pace of RMB gains; b) improvements in China's major BOP flow dynamics and sentiment on Chinese equities remains positive, especially ahead of the Victory Day Parade on 3 September; and c) state banks' FX actions may have been more subdued recently, though the potential for re- accumulation of FX remains. However, we believe the slow down in CNH underperformance is likely temporary because: 1) the recent slowdown in state banks' FX purchases in July may be temporary given the USD bid in the month and some evidence of official FX accumulation. Indeed, if there is an official stance to increase FX reserve coverage and if history holds, we expect DXY trending lower and onshore financial institutions' FX deposits to increase strongly; 2) there are signs that the PBoC may be a bit concerned over the recent pace of CNH appreciation. First, our daily fixing model error (actual fixing minus our model prediction) was just - 258pips today (29 Aug), which compares with - 422pips in the previous session. Second, the pass- through of our daily change in the model projection to the actual fixing was just \(17\%\) today, lower than the pass- through of \(49\%\) over the preceding five sessions; 3) we also

question whether there is a deliberate push to appreciate RMB. Despite the \(1.2\%\) appreciation of CNH against the USD in August, CNH CFETS was close to flat (i.e., \(+7bp\) only). This suggests USD/CNH has moved in tandem with the broad USD. In fact, our short CNH against the high- beta currencies (EUR, AUD, KRW) has gained 28bp in August (i.e., RMB has still underperformed); and 4) our economics team's outlook for a slower China macro backdrop in the coming months also suggests that RMB could underperform on a relative basis.

In Indonesia, we reduced the conviction (29 August) on our short USD/IDR trade to 3/5 (previous 4/5), targeting 15,500 by end- October. While there remains local uncertainty over protests, we believe USD/IDR should trend lower in the medium term because: 1) the impact of previous protests on IDR has tended to be limited and short- lived. We observe that in the previous examples of protests, depreciation pressures on IDR have been limited. 2) BI has remained active in the FX market, stabilizing the currency with interventions in FX spot, bond, domestic, and offshore NDF. Thus, a move higher in USD/IDR will likely be capped by BI. 3) Portfolio flows into Indonesia have been positive with MTD August equity inflows of USD744mn (1- 28 August), and bond inflows (1- 27August) of USD791mn; and 4) Powell was relatively dovish at the Jackson Hole symposium, which would likely keep the USD softer. He also highlighted upcoming benchmark revisions to nonfarm payrolls, which will likely lead to a large negative revision

In Korea, we maintain the conviction level on our short USD/KRW position at 3/5, targeting 1,300 ( \(- 5.4\%\) gains) by end- October (was end- September). Spot USD/KRW remained in the 1,380 to 1,400 range over the past week, though it did outperform within the Asia region with \(- 54bp\) in gains against the USD from 22 to 28 August (JPY gained 58bp). We continue to hold our KRW appreciation view because: 1) official confirmation that the US Treasury and Korean authorities are holding currency discussions. While we have not heard on this issue from the Korean delegation's visit to the US for the Trump- Lee Summit, BOK Governor Rhee said the FX discussions are ongoing with the US Treasury, and the US Treasury is also engaging with several Asian economies besides Korea (Bloomberg, 28 August). Governor Rhee also said that the BOK's FX intervention to limit KRW depreciation over the past 1- 2 years (i.e., sell USD; watch August FX reserves released on 3 September) may be viewed as desirable by the US Treasury. We would not rule out the risk that the US could push for currency appreciation among its trading partners, especially with our models showing that KRW is still undervalued by \(- 9.8\%\) on average; and 2) we believe Korea's exports and tech sector should remain supported by strong AI demand and rising chip prices. Despite Nvidia's tepid forecast of its third quarter revenue, the media reported (Bloomberg, 28 August) that at least 10 analysts updated their 12- month price targets owing to resilience AI demand. This bodes well for Korea's tech sector – watch Korea's August trade data released on 1 September.

In Taiwan, we maintain our short USD/TWD position with a conviction level of 3/5, targeting 29.0 ( \(- 5\%\) gains) by end- October. Other than a myriad of reasons for our medium- term weaker USD view, we see local factors providing some scope for TWD to appreciate because: 1) TWD has been the main laggard within the region since the start of July. DXY weakened by 2.1% from 1 July to- date, but TWD has depreciated the most by \(- 2.4\%\) against the USD within the region; 2) we believe recent TWD underperformance and lower short USD hedging costs (i.e., less negative swap points) also offer Taiwan lifers and exporters an opportunity to consider increasing their FX hedge ratio and reduce their USD hoarding respectively. The FSC noted that the Taiwan lifers' FX hedge ratio (including proxy hedge) stood at 63.4% as of end- July (Bloomberg, 29 August), which is relatively low; 3) market expectations for TWD appreciation might rise with BOK Governor Rhee's comment that the US Treasury is engaging in FX discussions with several Asian economies besides Korea (see above). Similar to KRW, we would not rule out that the US could push for currency appreciation in Taiwan too, especially with our models showing that TWD is still undervalued by \(- 7.4\%\) on average; and 4) relatively robust local fundamentals, supported by export resilience from secular AI demand. Taiwan's July industrial production growth remained solid at 18.1% y- o- y in July, led by strong chip production.
Fig.2:Our views on Asia FX

USD/JPY movements have been limited around the 147 level this week. The market's primary focus remains on US economic data, particularly the upcoming employment report and it will be crucial to see whether these indicators further bolster expectations for more aggressive US rate cuts. The market consensus for the NFP currently forecasts an \(80k\) increase for August, comparable with July's 73k gain, but a disappointing report might reignite expectations of a larger 50bp cut at the September FOMC, potentially causing heightened volatility in the currency markets and supporting JPY. In Japan, the ruling LDP is scheduled to hold a review of the Upper House election results at a general assembly on Tuesday. Depending on the party leadership decisions about a possible resignation, including Secretary- General Moriyama, pressure on PM Ishiba to step down could intensify. Even if the assembly passes without any major political moves, an opinion- gathering process on whether to hold an early leadership election is likely to commence, suggesting that political uncertainty will likely persist in the near term. We judge the risk of a major dovish shift in Japan's fiscal and monetary policies due to political moves has been reduced, but we need to monitor developments carefully for the next few weeks. We maintain our USD/JPY short recommendations, while cautiously monitoring the Japanese political situation.
Many are focused on the 8 September's vote of confidence in the French parliament, where the most likely outcome appears to be a loss for the current Prime Minister Bayrou,

but with limited negative implications for EUR. Our long EUR/CHF trade initially dropped on the announcement of the vote, but has rebounded somewhat, and we do not expect the ongoing French political saga to weigh more permanently on the EUR, as the relationship between OAT spreads and the currency is relative weak and unstable, as foreign holders of OATs that choose to sell can shift into other EUR- denominated bonds. In June 2024 the OAT- Bund 10y spread jumped from around 45bp to 80bp in less than two weeks and EUR/USD fell by little more than \(1\%\) . The latest jump in the yield spread is around half this size. The most negative scenarios for EUR would be if President Macron was unable to find a working coalition and ordered an election, or worse still, resigned himself. The latter, in particular, has a very low likelihood, in our view. French fiscal consolidation will be a challenge regardless, but the overall European fiscal picture is less worrisome. Apart from this, inflation data are unlikely to be a market mover, especially with ECB rate cut pricing for September having diminished considerably. But we still expect gradually improving economic momentum to now mean more cuts from the ECB this cycle, versus market pricing of a terminal rate around \(1.75\%\) . For Switzerland, we continue to see economic risks from a deteriorating export outlook and potential pharmaceutical tariffs. Survey data look bleak and a cut into negative territory remains highly plausible on 25 September.

We increase the conviction level on our short USD/SEK trade to \(4 / 5\) (from \(3 / 5\) previously, the trade was opened on 8 August) and continue to target a move to 9.00 by end- December, with the pair starting to gain a little more downside momentum over the last week on improving Swedish economic data and growing cyclical and institutional risks to the USD. GDP bounced back in Q2, with retail sales also improving further alongside the closely watched Economic Tendency Survey and consumer confidence. Inflation data on Thursday are likely to be higher than the Riksbank's forecasts again, and while the headline will likely be driven mainly by energy prices, we expect core measures to remain sticky and limit scope for another rate cut on 23 September. We have flagged USD/SEK's higher sensitivity to US front- end rates and see downside potential here following Jerome Powell's dovish slant at Jackson Hole and ongoing pressure from President Trump on the Fed following his announced firing of Governor Lisa Cook on 26 August.

AUD modestly outperformed NZD and CAD this week, supported by a high July CPI indicator print, which we think contained part signal but part noise. Steady- to- stronger market risk sentiment and the move lower in USD/CNH also appear to have helped AUD. The Australian Q2 GDP release is the highlight on the local calendar next week, and we have this tracking at a very respectable \(0.6\%\) q- o- q, slightly above the current Bloomberg consensus, and ahead of final data clues early next week. We think AUD/NZD could continue to grind higher, supported by stronger macro fundamentals in Australia, and perhaps by positioning too, based on CFTC data. However, it has already risen over recent weeks, broadly in line with wider short- end rate spreads, and we are reluctant to chase this higher, given the move to date, and as we think the New Zealand economy is in the process of bottoming out. We continue to see more upside for AUD/CAD, based on respective fundamentals and - just as important - our house view for a weaker USD trend.

Nothing major has happened in Canada this week that makes us change our relatively bearish CAD view. On 22 August, Canada decided to scrap some of its retaliatory tariffs against the US, effective 1 September, which is likely to reduce stagflationary risk in Canada. But since last Friday, the market's pricing for Bank of Canada policy rate cutting by end- 2025 is roughly unchanged at 25- 26bp, so the market hasn't viewed this news as significant. Governor Macklem also gave a speech regarding the Bank's review of its Monetary Policy Framework for 2026, though he reiterated that the BoC will continue targeting inflation at \(2\%\) , and he provided no major hints about new core inflation measures. Overall, amid the USD- driven FX market environment and a softer USD trend still continuing, we expect CAD to underperform against the Antipodean currencies. Next week, Canada's jobs report for August will be published on the same day as the US's, which could show some improvement from the previous month's weak print (was - 40.8k

m- o- m), as a leading indicator points to a recovery in August. Nevertheless, the US jobs report will likely have a stronger influence on our long AUD/CAD trade, as this may influence whether the market starts pricing in a 50bp cut at the September FOMC meeting.
Fig. 3: Our views on G10 FX

IGBs remain volatile, with 10y yields reaching \(6.66\%\) on Tuesday - the highest level since March this year and marking a 40bp sell- off from the lows. The market continues to worry about the supply of bonds (both IGBs and SDLs) in the market and remains cautious around auctions. Beyond the yield moves, we believe there are signs that the market has become somewhat disorderly (lower volumes, wider bid- ask, cancelled issuance, offshore- onshore spreads, etc). Furthermore, sentiment in the market is very poor, so, we believe that the RBI/GOI will likely soon take steps to support the bond curve. At a recent interview, the RBI governor noted how policy transmission through the government bond channel remains equally as important as the banking channel, and we published our view on what we believe is likely to be the tool of choice, noting bond buybacks or secondary market OMO purchases as favourites. Should such measures be announced we would look to add exposure in the 10y part of the bond curve, as we see scope for a 20- 25bp relief rally. Elsewhere, GDP rose \(7.8\%\) y- o- y against expectations of \(6.7\%\) . The NDOIS market has been much more rangebound, and we maintain our receive recommendation on the 2y NDOIS with a moderate conviction level (3/5), targeting a move to \(5.25\%\) by end- September.

This week IndoGB yields continued to grind lower, before reversing some of those gains today. Tuesday's auction continued to show strong demand from both onshore and offshore investors. The reversal was led by news of ongoing protests turning violent. Protests are very common within Indonesia, so protests are not a material risk; however, concerns over how new President Prabowo will handle them remains an unknown. In his address today, he tried to calm fears and provide some stability to the situation, though it clearly remains fluid and with more protests planned over the weekend, there could be a further intensification. Today's SRBI auction saw yields rise by 2- 7bp from last week and demand significantly lower. We have been recommending a long 5y IndoGB position, and we took profit on half last week after the surprise BI cut, but for now we retain the rest of the position with a moderate conviction (3/5), while retaining a target of \(5.5\%\) .
This week, Korea rates rallied into Thursday's MPC meeting but moved higher afterwards.

The BOK left its policy rate unchanged at \(2.50\%\) , with a slightly dovish tone (one dissenter, and five members voted for a cut over the next three months). That said, there were no hints on the terminal rate, and there remain concerns about the housing market. The market is currently pricing in slightly more than one cut in Korea over the next 12 months, well below the \(\sim 120bp\) in the US. On the fiscal situation, the 2026 budget proposal was released today, and KRW232trn is planned for KTB issuance. The number is slightly higher than KRW228.2trn for this year, after including the two extra budgets. Looking ahead, fiscal policy is likely to stay expansionary for the next few years, with the budget growing at \(4 - 5\%\) per year, and the debt/GDP ratio reaching \(58\%\) by 2029 (latest: \(49.1\%\) ). Thus, we remain cautious on long- end rates, but keep our receive Mar- 26 1y NDIRS vs. US recommendation with a conviction level of 4/5 for a lower terminal rate pricing. Next week, August trade and inflation data are published on Monday and Tuesday, respectively.

China rates moved in a narrow range this week. Liquidity is flush with the 7d repo fixing staying in the \(1.5 - 1.6\%\) range, much lower than that at end- July (1.60- 1.75%). The larger MLF net injection (RMB300bn) might be one reason for this. Onshore funds bought back some long- end bonds this week, but if we look at August as a whole, the flow remains net selling (but smaller than July). With onshore equity performance still holding up well, equity- bond market rotation should mean limited downside in rates (especially long- end). On bond supply, we expect net CGB and LGB issuance to stay elevated at \(\sim \mathrm{RMB}1.2-\) 1.3trn in September and October. Recent auctions showed weaker demand after the VAT recollection on interest income. Bond supply- demand dynamics are also supportive of higher rates in coming months. That said, for rates to move further higher, we may need more catalysts (stimulus or policies) or an improvement in fundamentals. We maintain a moderate conviction (3/5) in our pay Sep-IMM 5y NDIRS. Economic data wise, the August official and RatingDog manufacturing PMI will be out on Sunday and Monday.
Fig. 4: Our views on Asia and AUD rates

Previously, we asked "What is the MINIMUM gain in nonfarm payrolls (NEXT release on 5 September) required for the market to price - 75bp by end- 2025 (last - 56bp)?" In response, \(36.4\%\) of participants chose "+25k", \(22.7\%\) chose "+50k", \(15.9\%\) of participants chose "0", \(13.6\%\) of participants chose "-25k", and \(11.4\%\) of participants chose "-50k or lower".
Please see Strategy portfolio update (17 July 2025) for our full portfolio.

Nomura's Fixed Income Strategies express views on the price of securities and financial markets by providing trade recommendations. These

can be relative value recommendations, directional trade recommendations, asset allocation recommendations, or a mixture of all three. The analysis which is embedded in a trade recommendation would include, but not be limited to:

- Fundamental analysis regarding whether a security's price deviates from its underlying macro- or micro-economic fundamentals.- Quantitative analysis of price variations.- Technical factors such as regulatory changes, changes to risk appetite in the market, unexpected rating actions, primary market activity and supply/ demand considerations. The timeframe for a trade recommendation is variable. Tactical ideas have a short timeframe, typically less than three months. Strategic trade ideas have a longer timeframe of typically more than three months.
